speaker: Danielle
text: Okay, tell us a bit about yourself.

speaker: Erin
text: Yeah, I'm Erin. I am 22 years old. I just recently graduated from college, and right now I'm currently working as a research assistant and I'm also studying for an entrance exam for grad school.

speaker: Danielle
text: Do you currently use Canva?

speaker: Erin
text: I'm currently not using Canva, but I have used it in the past.

speaker: Danielle
text: And when you did use Canva, did you ever use the pro plan?

speaker: Erin
text: I did not, no.

speaker: Danielle
text: So, can you tell me about when and why you first started using Canva and what you mainly used it for?

speaker: Erin
text: Yeah, I think I mainly started using Canva in college, and it was mostly to create flyers for club events and things of that sort. I also remember using Canva because they had presentation templates as well, so I used Canva for some projects.

speaker: Danielle
text: And when did you stop using Canva, and what changed that led you to stop using it or use it less often?

speaker: Erin
text: I stopped using Canva because I graduated from school, and so there's not really a need for me to be creating flyers or club materials anymore since I'm no longer involved with those organizations.

speaker: Danielle
text: When you were using Canva in college, were you aware of the Canva Education platform and its features, as well as Canva for Campus and the partnerships with universities across the U.S.?

speaker: Erin
text: I have not heard of those plans, no.

speaker: Danielle
text: Were there any particular challenges or frustrations that made Canva harder to use or less valuable for you?

speaker: Erin
text: I didn't find Canva to be particularly challenging to use. I found the usability of the website to be very easy and suited my needs when I needed to create a graphic quickly.

speaker: Danielle
text: But if you were to point out any pain points, what would you bring up?

speaker: Erin
text: I think one of the pain points was when I was looking for certain graphics or icons. You weren’t able to sort between the Pro icons and the free plan. So if there was a way to filter between those two for icons, that would be helpful when looking for graphics I could actually use.

speaker: Danielle
text: And have you started using any other tools instead of Canva now that you’ve dropped off the platform? If yes, what do they offer that Canva didn’t?

speaker: Erin
text: I'm not using any graphic-making websites at the moment.

speaker: Danielle
text: It could also be digital materials in general—presentations, resume-building websites, any platform.

speaker: Erin
text: For my resume, I typically just use Word or Google Docs. I don’t need to be designing or adding icons, so there’s not a need for a site like Canva for that. As for presentations or projects, I haven't had to make anything that warrants a website like Canva. If I need to create a presentation, I typically use PowerPoint or Google Slides.

speaker: Danielle
text: And can you articulate why you fall back on those platforms now that you're out of college?

speaker: Erin
text: I think it's mostly because it's built into what I typically use. I’m very comfortable with Google Drive because I've used it throughout my education. In college, we used Microsoft applications like Word, PowerPoint, and OneDrive, so I’m comfortable with those. Also, the people I work with on my research project use those applications too, so it's easy to collaborate since everyone already has institutional access.

speaker: Danielle
text: Cool. So what university did you graduate from?

speaker: Erin
text: I graduated from Emory.

speaker: Danielle
text: And Emory is a Canva for Campus partner, I believe. Did you ever hear of any of your peers, professors, or clubs utilizing Canva for Campus?

speaker: Erin
text: I know that a few organizations used an upper level of Canva, but I'm not sure if that was directly related to the Canva for Campus plan.

speaker: Danielle
text: What would convince you to come back to using Canva in the future? Or why might you come back, if you foresee it happening?

speaker: Erin
text: Right now there’s just not a need for me to use an application like Canva, because I’m not creating high-level graphics or documents that require design elements like icons or photographs. If I ever needed something that required more design, I might return to Canva.

speaker: Danielle
text: Great. Is there anything else you'd like to touch on in terms of difficulties you find, or about the transition from college to newly graduated life?

speaker: Erin
text: Not particularly, no.

speaker: Danielle
text: Okay, great. Thanks.
